lg.l: Swift Dφ
Jn Ancient times, as Story tells,
The Saints would Often Leave their Cells,
And Strole about, but hide their Quality,
To try good people's Hospitality.
Jt Happen'd on a Winter Night,
As Authors of ye Legend write;
Two Brother Hermits, Saints by trade,
Taking their Tour in Masquerade;
Disguis'd in tatter'd Habitts went
To a Small Village down in Kent;
Where, in the Strolers Canting Strain,
They beg'd from Door to Door in Vain,
Try'd ev'ry Tone might pity win,
But not a Soul wou'd Let them in.Our Wand'ring Saints in Wofull State,
Treated at this Ungodly Rate,
Having thro' all the Village pass'd,
To a Small Cottage Came at Last;
Where dwelt a good old honest Yeoman,
Call'd in the Neighbourhood Philemon.
Who kindly did ye Saints Invite
Jn his poor Hutt to pass ye Night;
And then the Hospitable Sire
Bid Goody Baucis mend the fire;
While He from out of Chimney took
a Flitch of Bacon off the Hook;
And freely from the fattest side
Cut out Large Slices to be fry'd:
Then Step't aside to fetch ym drink,
Fill'd a large Jug up to the Brink;
And Saw it fairly twice go Round;
Yet (what is Wonderful) they found,
Twas still Replenish'd to the Top,
As if they ne'er had toucht a Drop.
The good Old Couple was Amaz'd,
And often on Each other Gaz'd;
For both were frighted to ye Heart,
And Just began to Cry;────What art!
Then Softly turn'd aside to View
Whether the Lights were burning blue
The Gentle pilgrims soon aware on't,
Told them their Calling & their Errant:
Good folks, You need not be afraid,
We are but Saints, the Hermits Said;
No hurt shall Come to You or Yours;
But, for that pack of Churlish Boors,
Not fitt to Live on Christian Ground,
They & their Houses shall be drown'd:
Whilst you shall See Your Cottage rise,
And grow a Church before Your Eyes.They Scarce had Spoke; when, fair & Soft,
The Roof began to Mount aloft;
Aloft rose ev'ry Beam and Rafter
The Heavy Wall Climb'd Slowly after.The Chimney widen'd, and grew higher
Became a Steeple with a Spire.
The Kettle to the Top was Hoist,
And there Stood fasten'd to a Joist:
But with the Upside down, to Shew
Jt's Jnclination for Below;
Jn vain; for a Superior force
Apply'd at Bottom, Stops it's Course,
Doom'd Ever in Suspence to Dwell
Tis now no Kettle but a Bell.
A Wooden Jack, which had Almost
Lost, by Disuse, the Art to Roast,
A Sudden Alteration feels,
Jncreas'd by New Jntestine Wheels:
And what Exalts the Wonder more,
The Number made the Motion Slow'r:
The flyer tho't had Leaden feet
Turn'd round so quick You Scarce cou'd See't;
But Slackned by some secret power,
Now hardly Moves, an Jnch an Hour.
The Jack and Chimney near Ally'd,
Had never Left Each other's Side;
The Chimny to a Steeple grown
The Jack wou'd not be Left alone
But up against the Steeple rear'd
Became a Clock and Still adher'd:
And Still it's Love to Houshold Cares
By a Shrill Voice at Noon Declares,
Warning the Cook·maid not to Burn
That Roastmeat which it Cannot turn.The Groaning Chair began to Crawl
Like a Huge Snail along the Wall;
There Stuck aloft, in publick View,
And with Small Change, a pulpit grew.The porringers that in a Row
Hung high & made a Glittering show
To a less noble Substance Chang'd
Were now but Leathern Bucketts rang'd.The Ballads pasted on the Wall
Of Joan of France, and English Moll,
Fair Rosamond, & Robbin Hood
The Little Children in the Wood:
Now Seem'd to Look abundance better,
Jmprov'd in picture Size & Letter;
And high in Order plac'd, describe
The Heraldry of Ev'ry TribeA Bedstead of ye Antique Mode,
Compact of Timber many a Load,
Such as our Ancestors did Use,
Was Metamorphos'd into Pews:
Which Still their Ancient Nature keep;
By Loding folks dispos'd to Sleep:
The Cottage by Such feats as these,
Grown to a Church by Iust Decrees,
The Hermits then desir'd their Host
To ask for what he fancy'd most:Philemon having paus'd a While
Return'd 'em thanks in Homely Stile;
Then Said; my House is grown so fine
Methinks, J Still wou'd Call it Mine:
J'm Old and fain wou'd Live at Ease
Make me the parson if You please.He Spoke & presently he feels,
His Grasiers Coat fall down his Heels;
He Sees, Yet hardly Can believe
About Each Arm a pudding Sleeve
His Wastcoat to a Cassock grew,
and both assum'd a Sable Hue;
But being Old, Continu'd Just
As threadbare and as full of Dust.
His talk was now of Tythes and Dues,
Cou'd Smoke his pipe and read the News,
Knew how to preach Old Sermons next
Vampt in the preface and the Text.
At Christnings well Cou'd act his part,
And had the Service all by Heart;
Wish'd women might have Children fast,
And thought whose Sow had farrow'd Last.
Against Dissenters wou'd repine,
And Stood up firm for Right divine
found his head fill'd with many a System
But Classic Authors────he Ne'er miss'd 'emThus Having furbish't up a parson
Dame Baucis next, they play'd their farce on:
Jnstead of Home-Spun Coifs were Seen,
Good Pinners Edg'd with Colberteen:
Her Petty·Coat transform'd a·pace
Became black Sattin, flounc'd with Lace.
Plain Goody wou'd no Longer down,
'Twas Madam in her Grogram Gown.Philemon was in great Surprize,
and hardly Cou'd believe his Eyes,
Amaz'd to See her look so prim,
And she Admir'd as much at Him.Thus happy in their Change of Life,
were Severall Years this Man and Wife;
When on a Day which prov'd their Last,
Discoursing on old Stories past,
They went by Chance amidst their Talk,
to the Church Yard to take a Walk;
When Baucis hastily Cry'd out;
My Dear I See Your forehead Sprout:
Sprout quoth the Man, What's this You tell us?
J hope You don't believe me Jealous:
But Yet, Methinks, J feel it true;
And truly Yours is budding too────
Nay────now J Cannot Stir my foot
Jt feels as if 'twere taking Root────Description wou'd but tire my Muse
Jn Short they both were turn'd to Yews.
Old Goodman Dobson of ye Green
Remembers, he the Trees has Seen;
He'll talk of them from Noon till Night
And goes with folks to Shew ye Sight:
On Sundays after Evening prayer,
He gathers all the parish there;
Points out the place of Either Yew
Here Baucis there Philemon grew
Till once a parson of our Town,
to mend his Barn Cutt Baucis down;
At which tis hard to be believ'd
How much the Other tree was griev'd:
Grew Scrubby, died a-top was Stunted,
So, the Next parson Stub'd & burnt it.090-903A
